1. Introduction

The Homematic IP Connect API enables you to write your own plugins to control, monitor or extend the Homematic IP system running on a Home Control Unit.

The API is available via WebSocket and provides a set of messages a plugin may send to or receive from the Home Control Unit. By implementing a specific flow of Connect API messages in your plugin, you can realize the following scenarios:

Include devices

Plugins can add third-party smart home devices to the Homematic IP system.

Control and monitor

Plugins can send commands to devices and groups and receive events whenever something changes in the Homematic IP system.

Regardless of your plugin’s specific functionality, there are two ways to run it:

Installed

Installed plugins run in a container environment on the Home Control Unit. To install your own plugin, you can build a container image with your application and upload it on HCUweb.

Remote

Remote plugins are applications running outside your Home Control Unit, such as from your IDE on your computer during development.

Tip
 Run your plugin remotely during development and testing. Once you are ready to test a version of your plugin on your Home Control Unit, you can create the container image and install it. Aside from a few differences in establishing the WebSocket connection, the source code of your plugin can remain the same, whether you’re running it remotely or as an installed plugin.

2. Getting Started

This step-by-step guide will get you started developing a plugin and running it remotely. After completing the steps you will be able to establish a connection to the Connect API WebSocket from outside your Home Control Unit and send and receive messages on that channel.

Note
 This chapter does not cover any instructions on how to build a container image and install a plugin on the Home Control Unit. Refer to the Containerization and the Example chapter for that.

2.1. Activate the developer mode

Using the Homematic IP Connect API requires the developer mode to be activated on your Home Control Unit.

  1. Open HCUweb and navigate to the developer mode page

  2. Press the button to activate the developer mode

Note
 You can access the "HCUweb" web service in your local network at https://hcu1-XXXX.local, where XXXX are the last four digits of the SGTIN found on the underside of the Home Control Unit.

2.2. Expose the WebSocket

Exposing the Connect API WebSocket in your local area network enables you to establish a connection from outside your Home Control Unit and run your plugin remotely.

  1. Open HCUweb and navigate to the developer mode page

  2. Activate the switch to expose the Connect API WebSocket

2.3. Define a plugin identifier

Using the Homematic IP Connect API requires a unique plugin identifier. This identifier is required to obtain an authorization token and must be included in the WebSocket connection request as well as in all subsequent messages.

It is recommended to use reverse domain name notation as a convention for plugin identifiers.

Tip
 This guide uses the plugin identifier de.doe.jane.plugin.example. You can customize it by replacing doe and jane with your last and first name, respectively.

2.4. Get an authorization token

To authorize the WebSocket connection request you need the authorization token of a Connect API client. Connect API clients are always assigned to exactly one plugin identifier. To create a client for your plugin identifier and obtain the authorization token, follow the steps below.

Note
 Creating a client this way is only necessary for plugins running remotely. The process is typically performed once by you and should not be part of the plugin itself.
Note
 After creating a Connect API client, the developer mode cannot be deactivated anymore.
Step 1: Generate an activation key

  1. Open HCUweb and navigate to the developer mode page

  2. Generate an activation key

    Note
    		 The activation key can be used only once and expires after a certain period.
Step 2: Request the authorization token

In the URL template, replace XXXX with the last four digits of the SGTIN found on the underside of your Home Control Unit to get your specific URL. Then, send a POST request to that URL including the required headers and JSON body. The authorization token will be included in the response body.

Note
 The Home Control Unit uses a self-signed certificate to provide HTTPS and WSS services. You can either handle the logic of trusting self-signed certificates at first connection or disable certificate validation.
URL template
https://hcu1-XXXX.local:6969/hmip/auth/requestConnectApiAuthToken
Request properties
Headers
Name Value

VERSION

12
Body schema
Name Type Description

activationKey

String

The activation key generated in the previous step

pluginId

String

Your plugin identifier

friendlyName

Map<String, String>

Key
ISO 639-1 language code

Value
A human readable, localized name of the plugin, displayed on HCUweb and in the Homematic IP smartphone app

Required keys:
de
Body example
{
    "activationKey": "ABCDEF",
    "pluginId":"de.doe.jane.plugin.example",
    "friendlyName": {
        "en":"Example Plugin",
        "de":"Beispiel-Plugin"
    }
}
Response properties
Body schema
Name Type Description

authToken

String

Authorization token of a Connect API client, pending confirmation in the next step
Body example
{
    "authToken": "B23FB0DC7FDAA140CDF679D5F78F047C16CEF349691A3E9B425DE16E291E51DF"
}
Step 3: Confirm the authorization token

Confirm the authorization token received in the previous step by sending it via HTTPS request to your Home Control Unit. The Home Control Unit will create a Connect API client and respond with a unique identifier of the created client. The authorization token is then confirmed and valid.

Note
 The client will appear in the user overview of the Homematic IP smartphone app along with smartphone users and other clients. Navigate there to delete your client if you no longer need it.

In the URL template, replace XXXX with the last four digits of the SGTIN found on the underside of your Home Control Unit to get your specific URL. Then, send a POST request to that URL including the required headers and JSON body.

URL template
https://hcu1-XXXX.local:6969/hmip/auth/confirmConnectApiAuthToken
Request properties
Headers
Name Value

VERSION

12
Body schema
Name Type Description

activationKey

String

The activation key generated in the first step

authToken

String

The authorization token received in the previous step
Body example
{
    "activationKey": "ABCDEF",
    "authToken": "B23FB0DC7FDAA140CDF679D5F78F047C16CEF349691A3E9B425DE16E291E51DF"
}
Response properties
Body schema
Name Type Description

clientId

String

Unique identifier of the Connect API client
Body example
{
    "clientId": "9fa276c2-b410-456d-bfde-4202918e8ce4"
}

2.5. Connect to the WebSocket

The Connect API WebSocket server of the Home Control Unit listens for new connections on port 9001.

In the URL template, replace XXXX with the last four digits of the SGTIN found on the underside of your Home Control Unit to get your specific URL. Then, send a connection request to that URL including your plugin identifier and authorization token as headers.

Tip
 API development and testing tools like Postman offer a simple way to connect to a WebSocket server, send messages, and receive responses.
URL template
wss://hcu1-XXXX.local:9001
Headers
Name Value

authtoken

The authorization token of the Connect API client you created in the previous step.

plugin-id

Your plugin identifier. Must be the same as the one used for creating the client.
Note
 For a complete description of the connection request properties, refer to the API Definition chapter.

2.6. Test the connection

  1. Open HCUweb and navigate to the plugin page. You should see a card with your plugin.

  2. Check your WebSocket connection. You should see a PluginStateRequest that was sent by your Home Control Unit when you opened the plugin page on HCUweb.

  3. To notify the system that your plugin is up and running, now send a PluginStateResponse. Include the same plugin identifier you used to establish the WebSocket connection, and set the pluginReadinessStatus to READY.

  4. Check the plugin page on HCUweb. You should see your plugin marked as running (READY).

2.7. Next steps

The Usage chapter explains typical flows of messages exchanged between plugins and the Home Control Unit.

When you are ready to run your plugin on your Home Control Unit, create a container image with your plugin and upload it via HCUweb. Image requirements and information about the container environment are covered in the Containerization chapter. Refer to the Example chapter for an example of writing a Dockerfile and step-by-step instructions of building the image.

3. Usage

This chapter covers a description of the intended usage of this API.

Typically, your plugin will implement one of the following scenarios:

  • Include devices

  • Control and monitor

Regardless of the scenario, the following flow is required:

  • Report the plugin state

Additionally, you can extend your plugin with the following functions:

  • Provide configuration options

  • Show messages in the app

3.1. Report the plugin state

Your plugin is always expected to send a PluginStateResponse to provide the Homematic IP system with status and meta information, as described below.

Send status and meta information to the Home Control Unit

Send a PluginStateResponse in the following situations:

  • Upon startup

  • Whenever the PluginReadinessStatus changes, e.g., from CONFIG_REQUIRED to READY after successfully applying a configuration update received via ConfigUpdateRequest

  • On receiving a PluginStateRequest from the Home Control Unit

Note
 When sending a message in response to a request sent by the Home Control Unit, your plugin should use that request’s message identifier in the response. Likewise will the Home Control Unit typically use the request’s message identifier in direct responses.

3.2. Include devices

To include third party smart home devices as plugin devices in the Homematic IP system, your plugin has to do the following:

  • Handle any incoming DiscoverRequest by sending a DiscoverResponse containing discovered plugin devices

  • Handle any incoming InclusionEvent by sending a StatusResponse containing states of all included plugin devices

  • Handle any incoming StatusRequest by sending a StatusResponse containing states of the requested plugin devices

  • Proactively send a StatusResponse or a StatusEvent whenever states of included plugin devices change

  • Handle any incoming ExclusionEvent by not sending states of the excluded devices anymore

  • Handle any incoming ControlRequest by controlling the included plugin device and sending a ControlResponse with the result (success or failure)

Note
 If your plugin is not designed to include plugin devices in the Homematic IP system, simply ignore incoming DiscoverRequest messages.
Intended flow of including plugin devices in the Homematic IP system

The diagram shows the intended flow of including plugin devices in the Homematic IP system:

  1. Upon startup, your plugin sends a PluginStateResponse with the status READY. Note that your plugin should always do this, regardless of whether it is designed to include plugin devices in the Homematic IP system or not.

  2. The Home Control Unit reacts by sending a DiscoverResponse.

  3. Your plugin discovers the third party devices that are available for inclusion in the Homematic IP system and maps them to plugin devices using the Device schema.

  4. Your plugin sends a DiscoverResponse containing the discovered plugin devices.

  5. The Home Control Unit includes the plugin devices in the Homematic IP system by adding them to the inbox.

  6. The Home Control Unit sends an InclusionEvent containing the identifiers of all included devices.

  7. Your plugin sends a StatusResponse containing states of all included plugin devices.

  8. The Home Control Unit updates the plugin device states in the Homematic IP system.

3.3. Control and monitor

To control the Homematic IP system, your plugin has to do the following:

  • Send an HmipSystemRequest with any suitable path, e.g. /hmip/device/control/setSwitchState to turn a Homematic IP switching device on or off

  • Handle the corresponding HmipSystemResponse to evaluate whether the request was successful

To also monitor the Homematic IP system state, e.g. to stay posted on the switch state of the Homematic IP switching device, your plugin further has to do the following:

  • Register for Homematic IP system events on establishing the WebSocket connection by including the hmip-system-events header

  • Upon startup, send an HmipSystemRequest with the path /hmip/home/getSystemState and cache the system state contained in the corresponding HmipSystemResponse

  • Handle any incoming HmipSystemEvent by replacing cached system parts with the updated parts contained in the event

Note
 It is not recommended to poll the system state via /hmip/home/getSystemState requests. Your plugin is expected to handle HmipSystemEvent messages to stay posted on the system state.
Intended flow to control and monitor the Homematic IP system

  1. On startup, your plugin sends an HmipSystemRequest with the path /hmip/home/getSystemState.

  2. The Home Control Unit sends an HmipSystemResponse containing the current state of the Homematic IP system.

  3. Your plugin initializes a cache with the system state.

  4. When triggered to control the system, your plugins sends an HmipSystemRequest to the Home Control Unit (see Homematic IP system requests for all available paths).

  5. The Home Control Unit sends an HmipSystemResponse, acknowledging that it received the request and will update the system accordingly.

  6. The Home Control Unit updates the system.

  7. If the system state changed as a result, the Home Control Unit sends an HmipSystemEvent containing a partial update of the Homematic IP system.

  8. Your plugin updates the cached system state by replacing the parts contained in the HmipSystemEvent.

3.4. Provide configuration options

To enable users to configure your plugin via HCUweb, e.g. to provide the address of a third party smart home bridge in the local network, your plugin has to do the following:

  • Handle any incoming ConfigTemplateRequest by sending a ConfigTemplateResponse containing a template with configurable parameters and associated constraints

  • Handle any incoming ConfigUpdateRequest by applying the configuration update and sending a ConfigUpdateResponse with the result or intermediate status

Tip
 Installed plugin running in a container on your Home Control Unit can use the /data directory to store configuration parameters that should persist across updates and application restarts (see Containerization).
Note
 If your plugin has no configuration parameters, it is recommended to handle the ConfigTemplateRequest by responding with an empty template.
Intended flow of configuring a plugin via HCUweb

  1. A user opens the configuration dialog of your plugin on HCUweb.

  2. The Home Control Unit sends a ConfigTemplateRequest to your plugin.

  3. Your plugin sends a ConfigTemplateResponse the the Home Control Unit, containing a template with configurable parameters and associated constraints.

  4. HCUweb uses the template to show a form with the configuration parameters to the user.

  5. The user updates the configuration and saves the changes.

  6. The Home Control Unit sends a ConfigUpdateRequest to your plugin, containing property identifiers and associated target values.

  7. Your plugin tries to apply the configuration update and sends a ConfigUpdateResponse to the Home Control Unit. Your plugin may repeat this step, i.e. send multiple responses.

Tip
 Send a response with the ConfigUpdateResponseStatus PENDING if your plugin cannot apply the configuration update directly. As soon as your plugin has successfully applied the configuration update, send a second response with the ConfigUpdateResponseStatus APPLIED. If user interaction is required, communicate this to the user via HCUweb by including a message in the response.

3.5. Show messages in the app

The Homematic IP Connect API enables your plugin to create user messages to be shown on the Home screen of the Homematic IP smartphone app.

Your plugin may do the following:

  • Create a new user message by sending a CreateUserMessageRequest

  • Delete a user message by sending a DeleteUserMessageRequest

  • Retrieve all user messages created by your plugin by sending a ListUserMessagesRequest and handling the corresponding response

  • Handle any incoming UserMessageAcknowledgementEvent

Tip
 Your plugin has to choose an identifier when creating a user message. If a user message with the same identifier already exists, the Home Control Unit will replace the existing with the new one.
Use unique identifiers like UUIDs to create single event-like messages, or static identifiers for self-replacing, status-like messages.

There are four different user message behavior types determining the intended flow of messages between your plugin and the Home Control Unit, each described below.

Intended flow of showing a message that users may dismiss

  1. Your plugin sends a CreateUserMessageRequest with behavior type DISMISSIBLE to the Home Control Unit.

  2. The Home Control Unit creates the user message and notifies the Homematic IP smartphone app to update the view.

  3. The Home Control Unit sends a CreateUserMessageResponse to your plugin.

  4. The user dismisses the message individually. Your plugin will not be notified about that.

Intended flow of showing a message that users may acknowledge by clicking OK

  1. Your plugin sends a CreateUserMessageRequest with behavior type ACKNOWLEDGEABLE_BY_OK to the Home Control Unit.

  2. The Home Control Unit creates the user message and notifies the Homematic IP smartphone app to update the view.

  3. The Home Control Unit sends a CreateUserMessageResponse to your plugin.

  4. The user clicks on the OK button of the message.

  5. The Home Control Unit sends a UserMessageAcknowledgementEvent with acknowledgement type OK to your plugin

  6. The Homematic IP smartphone app dismisses the message automatically.

Intended flow of showing a message that users may acknowledge by clicking YES or NO

  1. Your plugin sends a CreateUserMessageRequest with behavior type ACKNOWLEDGEABLE_BY_YES_NO to the Home Control Unit.

  2. The Home Control Unit creates the user message and notifies the Homematic IP smartphone app to update the view.

  3. The Home Control Unit sends a CreateUserMessageResponse to your plugin.

  4. The user clicks on the YES button of the message.

  5. The Home Control Unit sends a UserMessageAcknowledgementEvent with acknowledgement type YES to your plugin

  6. Your plugin handles the event and optionally sends a DeleteUserMessageRequest to dismiss the user message.

Intended flow of showing a message that users may not dismiss

  1. Your plugin sends a CreateUserMessageRequest with behavior type NOT_DISMISSIBLE to the Home Control Unit.

  2. The Home Control Unit creates the user message and notifies the Homematic IP smartphone app to update the view.

  3. The Home Control Unit sends a CreateUserMessageResponse to your plugin.

  4. At some point, your plugin sends a DeleteUserMessageRequest to dismiss the user message.

  5. The Home Control Unit sends a DeleteUserMessageResponse to your plugin.

4. Containerization

Installed plugins run in a container environment on the USB drive attached to the Home Control Unit. To install your own plugin, you need to build a container image and upload it via HCUweb. This chapter outlines the requirements and general information for the image. For practical guidance, including an example of a Dockerfile and step-by-step instructions of building the image, refer to the Example chapter.

4.1. Image requirements

  • The image must be built for an ARM64 platform.

  • The image should use an ARM64-compatible base image. A slim Alpine Linux base image is recommended to reduce resource usage and enable faster installations.

  • The image must include a label named de.eq3.hmip.plugin.metadata that contains metadata about your plugin. The value of this label must be a JSON string following the schema documented below.

  • The image must be compressed in a .tar.gz archive before uploading it via HCUweb.

Label schema
Name Type Description Required

pluginId

String

Unique identifier of the plugin

yes

issuer

String

Issuer of the plugin, e.g. your name

yes

String

Version of the plugin

yes

String

Minimal version of the Home Control Unit required by the plugin

yes

Indicates whether the plugin requires an internet connection or functions solely on the local network

yes

A human readable, localized name of the plugin, displayed on HCUweb and in the Homematic IP smartphone app

Required keys:

yes

Label example
{
	"pluginId": "de.doe.jane.plugin.example",
	"issuer": "Jane Doe",
	"version": "1.0.0",
	"hcuMinVersion": "1.4.7",
	"scope": "LOCAL",
	"friendlyName": {
		"en": "Example Plugin",
        "de": "Beispiel-Plugin"
	},
	"description": {
		"en": "This plugin includes devices in your Homematic IP system!",
		"de": "Dieses Plugin bindet Geräte in Ihr Homematic IP System ein!"
	},
    "settings": [],
	"image": "UExVR0lO",
	"changelog": "Version 1.0.0\n- Initial release",
	"logsEnabled": true
}

4.2. Container environment

Installed plugins running in a container on the Home Control Unit can connect to the Connect API WebSocket by sending a connection request to wss://host.containers.internal:9001.

Moreover, they have access to the following files and directories located in the root (/) of their container.

Available files and directories
Path Content

/TOKEN

File containing the authorization token of a Connect API client assigned to the plugin.

The Home Control Unit automatically creates the client when the plugin is installed. Installed plugins can use the token to authorize the connection request to the Connect API WebSocket server.

/CLIENTID

File containing a unique identifier of the Connect API client.

/SGTIN

File containing the SGTIN of the Home Control Unit.

The SGTIN can also be found on the underside of the Home Control Unit.

/data

Directory for persistent plugin data such as configuration parameters.

Files stored in the /data directory are preserved across updates and application restarts.

4.3. External access

To enable external access to services inside your container, such as a web server hosted by your plugin, you need to expose the relevant ports in your container. The Home Control Unit maps the exposed ports directly, meaning that if your plugin exposes port 8080, the service will also be accessible externally via port 8080.

Dockerfile instruction to expose port 8080
EXPOSE 8080

Your plugin may expose any ports greater than 1024, except the following:

Port Protocol

1883

tcp

6969

tcp

8428

tcp

8888

tcp

9000

tcp

9001

tcp

9293

tcp

9294

tcp

26969

tcp

5353

udp

43439

udp

5. Example

This chapter includes the Node.js implementation of a plugin-stub and instructions on how to run it on your computer, as well as a Dockerfile and the necessary steps to build a container image and install the plugin on the Home Control Unit.

The plugin simply sends a PluginStateResponse upon startup and whenever it receives a PluginStateRequest from the Home Control Unit. For simplicity, it does not include proper error handling or other safeguards. Refer to at it as a starting point for developing your own Node.js plugin or as a reference to understand the Homematic IP Connect API better.

Note
 This example uses the plugin identifier de.doe.jane.plugin.example. You can customize it, for example, by replacing doe and jane with your last and first name, respectively.
Copy the source code

Save the following source code in a file named plugin.js and store it in a working directory on your computer.

plugin.js
const WebSocket = require("ws");
const { v4: uuidv4 } = require("uuid");
const fs = require("fs").promises;

async function start(pluginId, host, authtokenFile) {
	const authtoken = await fs.readFile(authtokenFile, "utf8");
	
	const webSocket = new WebSocket("wss://" + host + ":9001", {
		rejectUnauthorized: false,
		headers: {
			"authtoken": authtoken,
			"plugin-id": pluginId
		}
	});

	function sendPluginReady(messageId) {
		const message = {
			id: messageId,
			pluginId: pluginId,
			type: "PLUGIN_STATE_RESPONSE",
			body: {
				pluginReadinessStatus: "READY"
			}
		};
		webSocket.send(JSON.stringify(message));
		console.log("Sent message:", JSON.stringify(message, null, 2));
	}

	webSocket.on("open", () => {
		console.log("Connected to WebSocket");

		// send PLUGIN_STATE_RESPONSE upon startup
		sendPluginReady(uuidv4());
	});

	webSocket.on("message", (data) => {
		const message = JSON.parse(data);
		console.log("Received message:", JSON.stringify(message, null, 2));

		// send PLUGIN_STATE_RESPONSE on receiving a PLUGIN_STATE_REQUEST
		if (message.type === "PLUGIN_STATE_REQUEST") {
			sendPluginReady(message.id);
		}
	});

	webSocket.on('error', (err) => {
		console.error('WebSocket error:', err.code, err.message || err);
	});
}

// parse command line parameters
const args = process.argv.slice(2);
const pluginId = args[0];
const host = args[1];
const authtokenFile = args[2];

// start the plugin
start(pluginId, host, authtokenFile);
Install the dependencies on your computer

Install Node.js and npm on your computer. Then, navigate to the working directory (where plugin.js is located) and run the following command to install the required npm packages. This will generate two files, package.json and package-lock.json, along with a directory containing the installed node modules.

npm install ws fs uuid
Run the plugin on your computer

  1. Get the authorization token of a Connect API client for the plugin identifier de.doe.jane.plugin.example. You may also use your own customized plugin identifier here.

  2. Store the authorization token in a file named authtoken.txt in your working directory.

  3. Lookup the SGTIN on the underside of your Home Control Unit.

  4. Replace XXXX by the last four digits of the SGTIN and run the following command in your working directory. If you are using a customized plugin identifier, also replace de.doe.jane.plugin.example.

    node plugin.js de.doe.jane.plugin.example hcu1-XXXX.local authtoken.txt
Note
 Running the plugin on your computer requires you to expose the Connect API WebSocket in your local area network.
Copy the Dockerfile

Copy the following Dockerfile to your working directory. If you are using a customized plugin identifier, make sure to update the entrypoint and label in the Dockerfile. You can also customize other fields of the label, as long as it meets the requirements.

Dockerfile
# Use an ARM64-compatible base image
FROM --platform=linux/arm64 ghcr.io/homematicip/alpine-node-simple:0.0.1

# Set the working directory inside the container
WORKDIR /app

# Copy package.json and package-lock.json
COPY package*.json .

# Install the required npm packages
RUN npm install

# Copy the executable
COPY plugin.js .

# Set the entrypoint to run the executable
ENTRYPOINT ["node", "plugin.js", "de.doe.jane.plugin.example", "host.containers.internal", "/TOKEN"]

# Set the plugin metadata label
LABEL de.eq3.hmip.plugin.metadata=\
'{\
	"pluginId": "de.doe.jane.plugin.example",\
	"issuer": "Jane Doe",\
	"version": "1.0.0",\
	"hcuMinVersion": "1.4.7",\
	"scope": "LOCAL",\
	"friendlyName": {\
		"en": "Example Plugin",\
		"de": "Beispiel-Plugin"\
	},\
    "description": {\
        "en": "This plugin was built with Node.js.",\
        "de": "Dieses Plugin wurde mit Node.js erstellt."\
    },\
	"logsEnabled": true\
}'
Note
 The Home Control Unit copies the /TOKEN file into the container when the plugin is installed (see Container environment). It contains the authorization token of a Connect API client automatically created for the plugin. There is no need to copy the authtoken.txt file into the image.
Build the image

From your working directory, run the following command to build the image. If you are using a different plugin identifier, update the image tag accordingly to maintain consistency.

docker build -t de/doe/jane/plugin/example:1.0.0 .
Export the image

Export the image and compress it in a .tar.gz archive.

docker save de/doe/jane/plugin/example:1.0.0 | gzip > plugin-1.0.0.tar.gz

If you are working on Windows, use the save command with the output option and then use a tool to compress the .tar file in a .tar.gz archive.

Windows
docker save de/doe/jane/plugin/example/node:1.0.0 -o plugin-1.0.0.tar
Install the plugin

Open HCUweb, navigate to the plugin page and upload the .tar.gz archive. The installation will be started automatically.

Note
 Installing developer plugins is only available while the developer mode is active on your Home Control Unit. If you don’t see the option to upload and install your own plugin, activate the developer mode first.

6. API Definition

6.1. WebSocket connection request

The Connect API WebSocket server of the Home Control Unit listens for new connections on port 9001. To establish the connection, your plugin has to send a connection request with the properties listed below.

Note
 The Home Control Unit uses a self-signed certificate to provide HTTPS and WSS services. You can either handle the logic of trusting self-signed certificates at first connection or disable certificate validation.
Connection request properties

Protocol

WSS

Host

For installed plugins, running in a container environment on your Home Control Unit:
host.containers.internal

For remote plugins, running outside your Home Control Unit in your local area network:
hcu1-XXXX.local, where XXXX are the last four digits of the SGTIN. The SGTIN can be found on the underside of the Home Control Unit.

Port

9001

URL Examples

wss://host.containers.internal:9001
wss://hcu1-1234.local:9001
Connection request headers
Name Description Required

authtoken

Authorization token of a Connect API client associated to the plugin identifier. Installed plugins can find their authorization token in the /TOKEN file located in the root directory of their container.

Example
B23FB0DC7FDAA140CDF679D5F78F047C16CEF349691A3E9B425DE16E291E51DF

yes

plugin-id

Unique identifier of your plugin

Example
de.doe.jane.plugin.example

yes

hmip-system-events

If true, your plugin will receive Homematic IP system events via WebSocket

Example
true

no

6.2. Envelopes

6.2.1. PluginMessage

Envelope for messages sent by Home Control Unit or plugins.

Example
{
  "pluginId": "de.doe.jane.plugin.example",
  "id": "38967997-e1b3-463f-8dc4-f889bb5d10a2",
  "type": "PLUGIN_STATE_REQUEST",
  "body": {}
}
Fields
Name Type Description Required

id

String

Message identifier, used in subsequent messages of the same flow.

yes

pluginId

String

Unique plugin identifier.

yes

type

PluginMessageType

Message type, defining the schema of the message body.

yes

body

Object

The body of the message, structured according to the message type.

Messages from plugin to Home Control Unit
Messages from Home Control Unit to plugin

no

6.3. Messages from plugin to Home Control Unit

This chapter includes a list of all messages that may be sent by the plugin.

Every message is wrapped in a PluginMessage and includes the unique identifier of the plugin, the PluginMessageType and a message identifier intended to be used in subsequent messages of the same flow.

Note
 If the message is the response to a request from the Home Control Unit, use the request’s message identifier in the response.

6.3.1. ConfigTemplateResponse

Message sent by the plugin containing a template with plugin configuration parameters and associated constraints. To improve usability, it is possible to order and group the properties. The message identifier must be identical to the one used in the preceding request.

Type

CONFIG_TEMPLATE_RESPONSE

Envelope

PluginMessage

Corresponding message

ConfigTemplateRequest
Example
{
  "pluginId": "de.doe.jane.plugin.example",
  "id": "38967997-e1b3-463f-8dc4-f889bb5d10a2",
  "type": "CONFIG_TEMPLATE_RESPONSE",
  "body": {
    "groups": {
      "exampleGroup": {
        "description": "Settings of gateway in the local network.",
        "friendlyName": "Network",
        "order": 1
      }
    },
    "properties": {
      "exampleProperty": {
        "minimumLength": 20,
        "defaultValue": "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet.",
        "dataType": "STRING",
        "values": [
          "RED",
          "GREEN",
          "BLUE"
        ],
        "groupId": "exampleGroup",
        "pattern": "^[A-Z]{5}$",
        "description": "IP-Address of the gateway.",
        "required": "true",
        "maximumLength": 255,
        "maximum": 99,
        "minimum": 1,
        "friendlyName": "Example parameter",
        "currentValue": "127.0.0.1",
        "order": 1
      }
    }
  }
}
Fields
Name Type Description Required

properties

Map<String, PropertyTemplate>

Property identifier to template mapping.

yes

groups

Map<String, GroupTemplate>

Group identifier to template mapping.

no

6.3.2. ConfigUpdateResponse

Message sent by the plugin containing the status of a configuration update. May be sent multiple times in case of a multi-step configuration update with required user interaction (e.g. button press on a gateway). The message identifier must be identical to the one used in the preceding request.

Type

CONFIG_UPDATE_RESPONSE

Envelope

PluginMessage

Corresponding message

ConfigUpdateRequest
Example
{
  "pluginId": "de.doe.jane.plugin.example",
  "id": "38967997-e1b3-463f-8dc4-f889bb5d10a2",
  "type": "CONFIG_UPDATE_RESPONSE",
  "body": {
    "message": "Please press gateway button to proceed.",
    "status": "APPLIED"
  }
}
Fields
Name Type Description Required

status

ConfigUpdateResponseStatus

Result or intermediate status of the configuration update.

yes

message

String

Optional feedback message containing further configuration steps or information to be shown to the user via HCUweb. The message shall be provided in the requested language according to the language code included in the request. Plugins may fall back to a default language.

no

6.3.9. PluginStateResponse

Message sent by the plugin containing the current plugin status. It should be sent when requested by the server, and proactively whenever a state change occurs. Typically right after starting the plugin, after configuration, or if an error occurs that requires user interaction. Include a map with human readable, localized names if you want to update your plugin’s name that is displayed on HCUweb and in the Homematic IP smartphone app.

Type

PLUGIN_STATE_RESPONSE

Envelope

PluginMessage

Corresponding message

PluginStateRequest
Example
{
  "pluginId": "de.doe.jane.plugin.example",
  "id": "38967997-e1b3-463f-8dc4-f889bb5d10a2",
  "type": "PLUGIN_STATE_RESPONSE",
  "body": {
    "pluginReadinessStatus": "READY",
    "friendlyName": {
      "en": "My plugin",
      "de": "Mein Plugin"
    }
  }
}
Fields
Name Type Description Required

pluginReadinessStatus

PluginReadinessStatus

Enumerated type of the plugin status, displayed on HCUweb.

yes

friendlyName

Map<String, String>

A human readable, localized name of the plugin. Keys must follow ISO 639-1 language codes. The key 'de' is required.

no

6.4. Messages from Home Control Unit to plugin

This chapter includes a list of all messages that may be sent by the Home Control Unit.

Every message is wrapped in a PluginMessage and includes the unique identifier of the plugin, the PluginMessageType and a message identifier intended to be used in subsequent messages of the same flow.

Note
 If the message is the response to a request from the plugin, the response’s message identifier will match the one of the request.

6.4.1. ConfigTemplateRequest

Message sent by the Home Control Unit to request a template with configuration parameters and associated constraints required by the plugin. The template will be used by HCUweb to present a form with the configuration parameters. The plugin may perform some work in the background before sending a response. That time should not exceed 10s.

Type

CONFIG_TEMPLATE_REQUEST

Envelope

PluginMessage

Corresponding message

ConfigTemplateResponse
Example
{
  "pluginId": "de.doe.jane.plugin.example",
  "id": "38967997-e1b3-463f-8dc4-f889bb5d10a2",
  "type": "CONFIG_TEMPLATE_REQUEST",
  "body": {
    "languageCode": "en"
  }
}
Fields
Name Type Description Required

languageCode

String

ISO 639-1 code of the language in which the configuration template shall be returned. Plugins may fall back to a default language. Required are english (en) and german (de)

no

6.4.2. ConfigUpdateRequest

Message sent by the Home Control Unit containing configuration parameter updates for the plugin in a key-value fashion. This message is sent whenever a user makes configuration changes for the plugin via HCUweb and saves them.

Type

CONFIG_UPDATE_REQUEST

Envelope

PluginMessage

Corresponding message

ConfigUpdateResponse
Example
{
  "pluginId": "de.doe.jane.plugin.example",
  "id": "38967997-e1b3-463f-8dc4-f889bb5d10a2",
  "type": "CONFIG_UPDATE_REQUEST",
  "body": {
    "languageCode": "en",
    "properties": {
      "stringProperty": "127.0.0.1",
      "numberParameter": 0.5,
      "integerParameter": 10,
      "booleanParameter": true,
      "enumProperty": "GREEN"
    }
  }
}
Fields
Name Type Description Required

languageCode

String

The plugin may include a feedback message in the response to this request. This field contains a ISO 639-1 code of the desired language for that feedback message. Plugins may fall back to a default language.

no

properties

Map<String, Object>

Property identifier to value mapping.

no

Corresponding message

6.5. Schemas

This chapter includes the documentation of schemas that are part of this API.

6.5.1. Device

Model for a plugin device to be included in a Homematic IP system.

Example
{
  "deviceType": "LIGHT",
  "features": [
    {
      "type": "switchState",
      "on": "true"
    }
  ],
  "modelType": "LTA004",
  "firmwareVersion": "1.2.3",
  "deviceId": "c0acf4e7-6e23-42cf-ae93-364f65b9e22a",
  "friendlyName": "White Ambiance light bulb"
}
Fields
Name Type Description Required

deviceId

String

Unique identifier of the device.

yes

deviceType

DeviceType

One of the supported device archetypes.

yes

features

Set<IFeature>

Supported features of the device. They must be either required or optional features of the corresponding device archetype.

no

firmwareVersion

String

The firmware version currently running on the device.

no

friendlyName

String

A describing label for the device.

no

modelType

String

A vendor specific model type.

no

6.5.2. Error

Schema of an error object that may be included in response messages sent by the plugin or Home Control Unit when an error occurs while processing a message.

Example
{
  "code": "BRIDGE_OFFLINE",
  "message": "Failed to process the request because the bridge is currently not responding."
}
Fields
Name Type Description Required

code

String

A code used to categorize the error, typically a number or enumerated type.

yes

message

String

An optional message that provides additional details or context about the error.

no

6.5.3. GroupTemplate

Template for a group in which properties are presented together.

Example
{
  "description": "Settings of gateway in the local network.",
  "friendlyName": "Network",
  "order": 1
}
Fields
Name Type Description Required

friendlyName

String

A human readable name of the group.

yes

description

String

A human readable description of the group.

no

order

Integer

The order of this group. HCUweb presents property groups sorted by order, starting with the lowest order at the top. Orders do not need do be sequential, i.e. gaps are possible (e.g. 0, 100, 300).

no

6.5.4. PropertyTemplate

Template for plugin configuration properties and associated constraints.

Example
{
  "minimumLength": 20,
  "defaultValue": "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet.",
  "dataType": "STRING",
  "values": [
    "RED",
    "GREEN",
    "BLUE"
  ],
  "groupId": "exampleGroup",
  "pattern": "^[A-Z]{5}$",
  "description": "IP-Address of the gateway.",
  "required": "true",
  "maximumLength": 255,
  "maximum": 99,
  "minimum": 1,
  "friendlyName": "Example parameter",
  "currentValue": "127.0.0.1",
  "order": 1
}
Fields
Name Type Description Required

dataType

PropertyType

Enumerated data type of the parameter.

yes

friendlyName

String

A human readable friendly name of the parameter.

yes

currentValue

String

The currently configured parameter value.

no

defaultValue

String

A default value for the parameter.

no

description

String

A human readable description of the parameter.

no

groupId

String

Identifier of the group in which HCUweb shall present this property.

no

maximum

Integer

A maximum value for numeric parameters like 'INTEGER'.

no

maximumLength

Integer

A maximum length for text based parameters like 'STRING' or 'PASSWORD'.

no

minimum

Integer

A minimum value for numeric parameters like 'INTEGER'.

no

minimumLength

Integer

A minimum length for text-based parameters like 'STRING' or 'PASSWORD'.

no

order

Integer

The order of this property. HCUweb presents properties sorted by order, starting with the lowest order at the top. Orders do not have do be sequential, i.e. gaps are possible (e.g. 0, 100, 300).

no

pattern

String

A pattern for text-based parameters like 'STRING' or 'PASSWORD' to match. The pattern has to be a regular expression with ECMAScript (JavaScript) syntax and semantics. The example contains a pattern for a string of exactly 5 letters from A to Z.

no

required

Boolean

Determines whether the parameter is required or optional.

no

values

List<String>

List of possible values a parameter may be set to. Applicable for text-based parameters with predefined values to choose from, like 'ENUM' or 'TYPEAHEAD'.

no

6.6. Types

This chapter includes a list of enumerated types used in the different schemas or messages that are part of this API.

6.6.1. AckType

Acknowledgement type of a user message created by a plugin to be shown in the Homematic IP smartphone app.

Value Description

NO

User acknowledged the message with NO. Applicable for user messages with BehaviorType 'ACKNOWLEDGEABLE_BY_YES_NO'.

OK

User acknowledged the message with OK. Applicable for user messages with BehaviorType 'ACKNOWLEDGEABLE_BY_OK'.

YES

User acknowledged the message with YES. Applicable for user messages with BehaviorType 'ACKNOWLEDGEABLE_BY_YES_NO'.

6.6.2. BehaviorType

Behavior type of a user message created by a plugin to be shown in the Homematic IP smartphone app. Used by app to enable the user to dismiss or acknowledge the message, or to prevent the user from dismissing it.

Value Description

ACKNOWLEDGEABLE_BY_OK

Users may acknowledge and thereby dismiss the user message in the Homematic IP smartphone app. The plugin will receive an acknowledgement event with AckType OK when the message is acknowledged.

ACKNOWLEDGEABLE_BY_YES_NO

Users may acknowledge the user message by selecting YES or NO in the Homematic IP smartphone app. The plugin will receive an acknowledgement event with AckType YES or NO when the message is acknowledged. The plugin may then dismiss the user message by sending a delete user message request.

DISMISSIBLE

Users may dismiss the user message in the Homematic IP smartphone app. The plugin will not receive an acknowledgement event when the message is dismissed.

NOT_DISMISSIBLE

Users may not dismiss the user message in the Homematic IP smartphone app.

6.6.3. ClimateOperationType

Enumerated type of climate operation modes. Used by plugin devices supporting the ClimateOperationMode feature.

Values

AUTO

COOLING

HEATING

6.6.4. ConfigUpdateResponseStatus

Describes the result or intermediate status of a plugin configuration update that was triggered by a HCUweb user by updating the plugin configuration and saving the changes.

Value Description

APPLIED

The plugin configuration update was applied successfully.

FAILED

The plugin configuration update could not be applied.

PENDING

The plugin configuration update is still pending, e.g. because applying it takes time or requires user interaction.

6.6.5. DeviceType

6.6.9. PluginReadinessStatus

Enumerated type of the plugin state. Included in a PluginStateResponse sent by the plugin to the Home Control Unit.

Value Description

CONFIG_REQUIRED

The plugin has to be configured to work as intended. This status should be used to communicate to users that they have to configure the plugin via HCUweb.

ERROR

The plugin could not be started, or any other unexpected error occurred. This status should be used to communicate to users that the plugin is not functioning as expected.

READY

The plugin is up and running. This status should be used to communicate to users that the plugin is ready for usage, typically right after startup or after successfully applying a configuration update.

6.6.10. PresenceType

Enumerated type of presence modes. Used by plugin devices supporting the PresenceMode feature.

Values

AWAY

DEFAULT

HOME

NORMAL

VACATION

6.6.11. PropertyType

Enumerated data type of a plugin configuration property defined in a property template.

Value Description

BOOLEAN

Type for boolean properties.

ENUM

Type for property with a predefined set of values. In the property template, use the field 'values' to provide the set of possible values.

INTEGER

Type for integer properties. In the property template, use the fields 'minimum' and 'maximum' to define constraints.

NUMBER

Type for floating point number properties. In the property template, use the fields 'minimum' and 'maximum' to define constraints.

PASSWORD

Type for password properties. Will be displayed obscured.

QRCODE

Type for QR code properties. In the property template, use the field 'currentValue' for the text used to generate the QR code.

READONLY

Type for string properties that cannot be modified by user. In the property template, use the field 'currentValue' for the read-only text.

STRING

Type for string properties. In the property template, use the fields 'minimumLength', 'maximumLength' and 'pattern' to define constraints.

TYPEAHEAD

Type for string properties with autocompletion. In the property template, use the field 'values' for a list of possible values the user may select while typing.

WEBLINK

Type for for weblink properties. In the property template, use the field 'currentValue' for the link and the field 'defaultValue' for additional info text.

6.6.12. ShadingDirection

Enumerated type of shading directions. Used by plugin devices supporting the ShutterDirection feature.

Values

DARKER

LIGHTER

6.8. Homematic IP system requests

This chapter documents the available paths and their corresponding bodies that plugins may send via HmipSystemRequest.

Note
 The Home Control Unit always responds with a HmipSystemResponse. The message identifier of the response will the one of the request.
Note
 If a Homematic IP system request triggers changes in the Homematic IP system, the Home Control Unit will notify the plugin via HmipSystemEvent.

6.8.1. /hmip/device/control/

6.8.1.1. acknowledgeFrostProtectionError

Path

/hmip/device/control/acknowledgeFrostProtectionError

Description

Acknowledges the frost protection error for a device channel.

Error Codes

INVALID_REQUEST
INVALID_AUTHORIZATION
FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED
INTERNAL_ERROR
CLIENT_VERSION_NOT_SUPPORTED
DATA_TRANSFER_IN_PROGRESS
LIVE_OTAU_IN_PROGRESS
NOT_ALLOWED_DURING_AP_EXCHANGE
UNKNOWN_DEVICE
UNKNOWN_CHANNEL
CLIENT_ACCESS_DENIED
Body schema
Name Type Description

deviceId

String

The identifier of the device targeted by the request

channelIndex

int

The index of the device channel targeted by the request
Request example
{
  "pluginId": "de.doe.jane.plugin.example",
  "id": "38967997-e1b3-463f-8dc4-f889bb5d10a2",
  "type": "HMIP_SYSTEM_REQUEST",
  "body": {
    "path": "/hmip/device/control/acknowledgeFrostProtectionError",
    "body": {
      "channelIndex": 0,
      "deviceId": "8d324121-2392-438e-87d7-003247e5de18"
    }
  }
}
Response example
{
  "pluginId": "de.doe.jane.plugin.example",
  "id": "38967997-e1b3-463f-8dc4-f889bb5d10a2",
  "type": "HMIP_SYSTEM_RESPONSE",
  "body": {
    "code": 200
  }
}
6.8.1.2. pullLatch

Path

/hmip/device/control/pullLatch

Description

Triggers the latch of a door opening device by activating the switching output of the target device channel for the configured duration.

Error Codes

INVALID_REQUEST
INVALID_AUTHORIZATION
FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED
INTERNAL_ERROR
CLIENT_VERSION_NOT_SUPPORTED
DATA_TRANSFER_IN_PROGRESS
LIVE_OTAU_IN_PROGRESS
NOT_ALLOWED_DURING_AP_EXCHANGE
UNKNOWN_DEVICE
UNKNOWN_CHANNEL
INVALID_AUTHORIZATION_PIN
CLIENT_INVALID_AUTHORIZATION
CLIENT_ACCESS_DENIED

Notes

Both the requesting client and the target device channel must belong to the same access authorization.
Body schema
Name Type Description

authorizationPin

String

The PIN of the access authorization to which the target device channel is assigned as an actuator

deviceId

String

The identifier of the device targeted by the request

channelIndex

int

The index of the device channel targeted by the request
Request example
{
  "pluginId": "de.doe.jane.plugin.example",
  "id": "38967997-e1b3-463f-8dc4-f889bb5d10a2",
  "type": "HMIP_SYSTEM_REQUEST",
  "body": {
    "path": "/hmip/device/control/pullLatch",
    "body": {
      "authorizationPin": "6942",
      "channelIndex": 1,
      "deviceId": "d00710c4-2392-438e-87d7-8d324121de18"
    }
  }
}
Response example
{
  "pluginId": "de.doe.jane.plugin.example",
  "id": "38967997-e1b3-463f-8dc4-f889bb5d10a2",
  "type": "HMIP_SYSTEM_RESPONSE",
  "body": {
    "code": 200
  }
}

  "pluginId": "de.doe.jane.plugin.example",
  "id": "38967997-e1b3-463f-8dc4-f889bb5d10a2",
  "type": "HMIP_SYSTEM_REQUEST",
  "body": {
    "path": "/hmip/device/control/resetEnergyCounter",

    "code": 200,
    "body": {
      "activationProblems": [
        "AP_COMMNUICATION"
      ],
      "channelActivationProblems": {}
    }
  }
}

6.9. Homematic IP system events

This chapter documents the various types of push events that may be sent via HmipSystemEvent by the Home Control Unit to notify plugins about changes in the Homematic IP system.

Note
 To register for Homematic IP system events, the plugin has to include the hmip-system-events header in the connection request to the Connect API WebSocket server.

The eventTransaction field of the HmipSystemEvent message contains a transaction object of the schema documented below. As a change in the system often affects different system components, an event transaction often may contain multiple push events. For example, when all switching devices of a room are turned on, the state of the room’s switching group will change, as well as all devices assigned to the group.

Every push event has a field pushEventType determining the specific push event schema. The different types are covered in the sections of this chapter.

Event transaction schema
Name Type Description

accessPointId

String

The SGTIN which can be found on the underside of the Home Control Unit.

events

Map<Integer,Object>

A map containing one or more push events. The key is an index determining the order in which the push events should be handled (lowest index first).

origin

Object

The instance that triggered the Homematic IP system event.

6.9.1. HOME_CHANGED

This event will be sent whenever the home object of the Homematic IP system changes. Plugins that maintain the state of the home object should handle this event by replacing their cached version with the updated object.

Schema
Name Type Description

pushEventType

String

Value: HOME_CHANGED

home

Object

The updated home object

6.9.2. DEVICE_ADDED

This event will be sent whenever a new device is added to the Homematic IP system. Plugins that maintain a list of devices, including their state parameters and meta information, should handle this event by adding the new device object to the cached list.

Schema
Name Type Description

pushEventType

String

Value: DEVICE_ADDED

device

Object

The new device object

6.9.3. DEVICE_CHANGED

This event will be sent whenever a device object in the Homematic IP system changes. The event includes the complete device object, containing the up-to-date values of all state parameters and metadata. Plugins that maintain a list of devices should handle this event by replacing the cached device object with the updated version. The id field of the device object serves as a unique identifier and should be used for matching.

Schema
Name Type Description

pushEventType

String

Value: DEVICE_CHANGED

device

Object

The updated device object

6.9.4. DEVICE_REMOVED

This event will be sent whenever a device is removed from the Homematic IP system. Plugins that maintain a list of devices should handle this event by removing the cached device object whose id matches the identifier provided in the event.

Schema
Name Type Description

pushEventType

String

Value: DEVICE_REMOVED

id

String

The identifier of the removed device

6.9.5. GROUP_ADDED

This event will be sent whenever a new group is added to the Homematic IP system. Plugins that maintain a list of groups should handle this event by adding the new group object to the cached list.

Schema
Name Type Description

pushEventType

String

Value: GROUP_ADDED

group

Object

The new group object

6.9.6. GROUP_CHANGED

This event will be sent whenever a group object in the Homematic IP system changes. Plugins that maintain a list of groups should handle this event by replacing the cached group object with the updated version. The id field of the group object serves as a unique identifier and should be used for matching.

Schema
Name Type Description

pushEventType

String

Value: GROUP_CHANGED

group

Object

The updated group object

6.9.7. GROUP_REMOVED

This event will be sent whenever a group is removed from the Homematic IP system. Plugins that maintain a list of groups should handle this event by removing the cached group object whose id matches the identifier provided in the event.

Schema
Name Type Description

pushEventType

String

Value: GROUP_REMOVED

id

String

The identifier of the removed group

6.9.8. CLIENT_ADDED

This event will be sent whenever a new client (e.g. a smartphone user) is added to the Homematic IP system. Plugins that maintain a list of clients should handle this event by adding the new client object to the cached list.

Schema
Name Type Description

pushEventType

String

Value: CLIENT_ADDED

client

Object

The new client object

6.9.9. CLIENT_CHANGED

This event will be sent whenever a client object in the Homematic IP system changes, e.g. when a smartphone user changes the client label. Plugins that maintain a list of clients should handle this event by replacing the cached client object with the updated version. The id field of the client object serves as a unique identifier and should be used for matching.

Schema
Name Type Description

pushEventType

String

Value: CLIENT_CHANGED

client

Object

The updated client object

6.9.10. CLIENT_REMOVED

This event will be sent whenever a client (e.g. a smartphone user) is removed from the Homematic IP system. Plugins that maintain a list of clients should handle this event by removing the cached client object of which the id field matches the identifier provided in the event.

Schema
Name Type Description

pushEventType

String

Value: CLIENT_REMOVED

id

String

The identifier of the removed client

6.9.11. SECURITY_JOURNAL_CHANGED

Informatory event that will be sent on changes of the event journal. Not relevant for plugins.

Schema
Name Type Description

pushEventType

String

Value: SECURITY_JOURNAL_CHANGED

6.10. Homematic IP system error codes

A HMIP_SYSTEM_RESPONSE sent by the Home Control Unit in response to a HmipSystemRequest includes an HTTP-based return code and, optionally, a body object. In case of an error, the body contains the String representation of a more detailed error code.

Body schema
Name Type Description

errorCode

String

String representation of a Homematic IP system error code
Example
{
  "pluginId": "de.doe.jane.plugin.example",
  "id": "38967997-e1b3-463f-8dc4-f889bb5d10a2",
  "type": "HMIP_SYSTEM_RESPONSE",
  "body": {
    "code": 400,
    "body": {
      "errorCode": "FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED"
    }
  }
}
Available error codes

1000 - CONCURRENT_MODIFICATION
used when trying to access an object that has been concurrently removed (e.g. trying to retrieve the status of a group that has concurrently been removed by another client)

1001 - UNKNOWN_REQUEST
used when an url is called that does not reflect a valid request

1400 - INVALID_REQUEST
used when a request has missing or invalid parameters

1401 - INVALID_AUTHORIZATION
used when the auth token of a request is not valid

1402 - INVALID_PIN
used when the pin of a request is required and the passed pin is incorrect

1403 - FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED
used when parameters of request are okay but the specified object does not support this feature

1404 - FEATURE_NOT_ENABLED
used if a server feature is not (yet) enabled

1405 - NOT_ALLOWED_PLUGIN_ID
used when given pluginId is not allowed

1500 - INTERNAL_ERROR
used if the server encountered an internal processing error

1502 - THIRD_PARTY_SERVICE_ERROR
used if a third party server encountered an internal processing error

1600 - CLIENT_VERSION_NOT_SUPPORTED
used if the client API version that sends the request is not supported

1601 - INVALID_PARAMETER_VALUE
used if the value is not in the given range

1602 - INVALID_PARAMETER_VALUE_LENGTH
used if the value has not a valid length

1603 - INVALID_PARAMETER_SIZE
used if the value has not a valid size

1604 - INVALID_NUMBER_PARAMETER_VALUE
used if the number value is not in the given range

1605 - INVALID_MULTIPLE_NUMBER_PARAMETER_VALUE
used if the number value is not in the given range invalid multiple number values

1700 - DATA_TRANSFER_IN_PROGRESS
used if the migration was already triggered for the access point

1800 - LIVE_OTAU_IN_PROGRESS
used if a live OTAU is in progress and the command can not be executed

1900 - NOT_ALLOWED_IN_OFFLINE_MODE
used if a feature is currently not supported due to offline mode

2002 - PENDING_DEVICE_INCLUSION_PROCESS
used the inclusion or exchange process is already in process by another device

2003 - UNRECOGNIZED_TIMEZONE
used if the given timezone id could not be resolved

2004 - SOLUTION_NOT_ACTIVE
used if the given solution is not active

2005 - PENDING_EXTERNAL_DEVICE_DISCOVERY
used if external devices are already being discovered by another client

2006 - NOT_ALLOWED_DURING_INITIALIZATION
used if the request is not allowed during the system initialization

2007 - NOT_ALLOWED_AFTER_INITIALIZATION
used if the request is only allowed during the system initialization or is only allowed to be done once (until reset)

2301 - NOT_ALLOWED_DURING_ACTIVE_ALARM
used if the request is not allowed during active alarm

2302 - NOT_ALLOWED_DURING_AP_EXCHANGE
used if the request is not allowed during access point exchange

2303 - NOT_ALLOWED_DURING_COOLING
used if the request is not allowed if cooling is active

2304 - COOLING_NOT_ENABLED
used if the request is not allowed if cooling is inactive

2305 - COOLING_EXTERNALLY_CONTROLLED
used if the request is not allowed if cooling is externally controlled

2306 - NOT_ALLOWED_DURING_ABSENCE_MODE
used if the request is not allowed if economy mode is active

2307 - NOT_ALLOWED_DURING_ACTIVE_PROTECTION
used if the C2C command is not allowed during active protection mode

2308 - ACCESS_POINT_NOT_CONNECTED
used if the command is not done and access point is not connected

2309 - ACCESS_POINT_REMOTE_ACCESS_DENIED
used if the command is not done because the remote access to the access point is not allowed

3001 - UNKNOWN_GROUP
used if the group with the given id is not known

3002 - NOT_HEATING_GROUP
used if the group with the given id is not a HEATING group

3003 - MAXIMUM_GROUP_LIMIT_REACHED
used the inclusion process is already in process by another device

3004 - NOT_SWITCHING_GROUP
used if the group with the given id is not any type of switching group

3005 - NOT_ALARM_SWITCHING_GROUP
used if the group with the given id is not a HEATALARM_SWITCHINGING group

3006 - NOT_META_GROUP
used if the group with the given id is not a META group

3007 - NOT_EXTENDED_LINKED_SWITCHING_GROUP
used if the group with the given id is not a EXTENDED_LINKED_SWITCHING group

3008 - NOT_SHUTTER_GROUP
used if the group with the given id is not a any type of shutter group

3009 - INVALID_GROUP_TYPE
used if the group with the given id is not a valid one for the request

3010 - NOT_LOCK_PROFILE_GROUP
used if the group with the given id is not a LOCK_PROFILE group

3011 - NOT_AUTO_RELOCK_PROFILE_GROUP
used if the group with the given id is not a AUTO_RELOCK_PROFILE group

4001 - UNKNOWN_DEVICE
used if the device with the given id is not known

4002 - INVALID_ASSIGNMENT_SOURCE
used if the source group of the device is not allowed

4003 - INVALID_ASSIGNMENT_TARGET
used if the target group for the device is not allowed

4004 - INVALID_ASSIGNMENT_DEVICE
used if the device is invalid for the assignment

4005 - ASSIGNMENT_LOCKED
used if the assignment is locked

4006 - MAXIMUM_GLOBAL_DEVICE_LIMIT_REACHED
used if the maximum number of devices or devices of the connection type for the installation is reached

4007 - MAXIMUM_GROUP_DEVICE_LIMIT_REACHED
used if the maximum number of devices in a group is reached

4008 - MAXIMUM_GROUP_LIMIT_FOR_DEVICE_TYPE
used if the maximum number of devices of a specific type or functional family in a group is reached

4009 - UPDATE_NOT_APPLICABLE
used if the device could be updated but other requirements have not been fulfilled

4010 - INVALID_ASSIGNMENT_TARGET_GROUP_TYPE
used if the type of the target group for the device is not allowed

4011 - INVALID_ASSIGNMENT_SOLUTION_COMBINATION
used if the solution combination for the device is not allowed

4012 - INVALID_ASSIGNMENT_DEVICE_CHANNEL_TYPE
used if the type of the device channel is invalid for the assignment

4013 - MAXIMUM_DEVICE_CHANNEL_LIMIT_USAGE_REACHED
used if the maximum number of device channels is reached

4014 - NOT_READY_FOR_UPDATE
used if the device update is not ready to be applied

4015 - UPDATE_SLOT_NOT_AVAILABLE
used if the no slot for the update is available

4016 - UPDATE_FILE_NOT_AVAILABLE
used if the no file for the update is available

4017 - DEVICE_UNREACHABLE
used if the device is unreachable

4018 - DEVICE_BUSY
used if the device is in a busy state and cannot perform the requested operation

4101 - UNKNOWN_CHANNEL
used if the device channel with the given id and index is not known

4201 - UNKNOWN_CHANNEL_GROUP
used if the device channel group with the given id and index is not known

4402 - INVALID_AUTHORIZATION_PIN
used if the call requires a authorization pin and the passed pin is incorrect

5001 - UNKNOWN_CLIENT
used if the client with the given id is not known

5002 - NOT_ALLOWED_FOR_LAST_ADMIN
used if the client with the given id is the last client with admin role with initialized credentials and URM is active

5401 - CLIENT_INVALID_AUTHORIZATION
used if the request is not allowed for this client (at the moment)

5402 - CLIENT_ACCESS_DENIED
used if the client is lacking permission for the request

5403 - CLIENT_INVALID_RECOVERY_CODE
used if the recovery code of the request is incorrect

6001 - UNKNOWN_RULE
used if the rule with the given id is not known

6002 - INVALID_RULE_TYPE
used if the type of the rule is not valid

6003 - INVALID_ASSIGNMENT_ACTION
used if one or more assigned actions of the rule is not valid

6004 - INVALID_ASSIGNMENT_CONDITION
used if one or more conditions actions of the rule is not valid

6005 - INVALID_ASSIGNMENT_TRIGGER
used if one or more triggers actions of the rule is not valid
